Award.AwardTitle: Bio-Informed Framework Enabling Multimetric Infrastructure Monitoring

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of this US-Korea-Japan research effort is to develop a transformative framework for Wireless Smart Sensor Networks (WSSN) to monitor critical civil infrastructure that builds upon a foundation of substantial existing collaboration with our international counterparts. To achieve the project goal, four principal tasks are defined: 1) Develop multi-metric and multi-scale sensors and associated algorithms that are informed by the sensory perception of biological organisms; 2) Implement a service-oriented architecture that will result in modular, easy to maintain applications that can be adapted for monitoring different types of structures and will manage the complexity demanded by multi-metric sensing; 3) Develop a user-driven WSSN macro-programming environment to facilitate the implementation of structural health monitoring for critical civil infrastructure; and 4) Prototype and test the WSSN by implementing the developed software in both laboratory and full-scale test beds. The benefits of this approach include greatly improving the scalability of the software development process, enabling multiple dynamic, context-aware applications to run concurrently in a shared environment, and increasing efficiency through global shared resource management across applications. Successful completion of this research will accelerate the practical implementation of innovative strategies for protecting our respective nations infrastructure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Though the basic hardware required to form a wireless smart sensor network has existed for more than a decade, full-scale deployment for civil engineering structures has been extremely limited. The reason for the small number of deployments can be attributed to a number of issues, including: (i) previous sensor boards possessed low-quality A/D converters that could not provide precise sampling rates and timings; (ii) high-quality, user-selectable antialiasing filters were unavailable, (iii) appropriate software was lacking to deliver the synchronization of the nodes (microsecond) needed for vibration analysis. This research developed the concepts and theories to overcome these challenges and deliver the wireless smart sensor hardware and the associated software that has been adopted and is being used by over 75 research groups in 15 countries.  This number continues to grow as research interest in wireless structural health monitoring grows, the field will see an acceleration of technology development and a growing number of commercial field deployments.

This research has pioneered an open-source, customizable hardware and software framework for wireless smart sensors that has resulted in an inexpensive, commercially-available, wireless sensor platform that is able to deliver the high-fidelity and high-precision data needed for vibration monitoring of civil, mechanical, and aerospace structures. The innovative hardware developments created under this project are complimented by pioneering work in the creation of scalable data interrogation methods that process wireless sensor data to assess structural health conditions. Because wireless sensor networks represent a highly distributed computing platform, successful data interrogation algorithms must be distributed across a large number of nodes with tight synchronization in their execution. These innovative strategies for the embedment of structural health monitoring algorithms on wireless smart sensor networks are coming to be viewed as the gold standard for the field.

New algorithms have been developed that take advantage of the availability of a variety of measurands at multiple temporal and spatial scales. Traditional SHM approaches using wireless sensor networks emulate wired sensors and employ only acceleration measurements to conduct damage detection. Acceleration measurements capture the global response of a structure; however, damage in structures is an intrinsically local phenomenon. Acceleration measurements yielding the global responses of a structure have been combined with dynamic structural strains which provide an indicator of local structural behavior. By fusing together multi-scale sensed data, he can achieve more accurate assessment of structural behavior and health.

New decentralized modal analysis and damage detection strategies that can be implemented on dense arrays of smart wireless sensors have been developed. In this approach, clusters of wireless sensors work together to determine local modes shapes, which is a type of model-based data aggregation. This compact form of the dynamic data is then transferred back to the base station where it can be knit together to give the global modal behavior of the structure and identify potential damage sites. In addition, the implementation of flexibility-based damage detection approaches for real-time execution on a wireless sensor network have been simplified.
